captions.text: Well, I guess January is still catchup
season. Or should I say batch chup
season. Yes, I finally got me greasy
come stained mitts on a Meta Quest 3
recently. Short review, more powerful.
Still love that it&#39;s wireless. Still
hangs off the front of my face like a
fat orphan koala. More importantly, it
allowed me to play that new Batman VR
game everyone&#39;s been saying is great, or
at least better than the previous Batman
VR game, which in terms of bars to clear
as a Snickers resting on two pencils.
First impressions weren&#39;t great. I know
the Batman Arkham series has long been
grouped with Sonic the Hedgehog in the
realm of create titles just by jamming
random words on the end of the franchise
word. But it&#39;s still disappointing they
went with Shadow. They got it out before
Assassin&#39;s Creed used it at least, which
is officially the point of becoming
completely hackneed, but they cut it
[ __ ] fine. Anyway, in contrast to the
first Arkham VR, which was a classic
tech demo style early VR game, stand
rooted to the spot and do the thing that
makes the next thing happen, Arkham
Shadow is actually a full-on Arkham
game, meaning you can actually move,
shock, and as well as do the thing that
makes next things happen. Do other
things that make irrelevant things
happen. Horror, astoundment, hushed
whispers amid the academics. The plot is
a direct sequel to Arkham Origins,
meaning this is the the Batman we have
at home, Batman as opposed to the Conroy
classic. But what do you want? Poor [ __ ]
is dead. Batman cannon tends to be
flexible. There&#39;s what, 12 versions of
it in film alone now. So, here&#39;s how the
dice fell this time. Batman&#39;s parents
were killed by Joe Chill. Check. But now
he was raised by Leslie Tommpkins
instead of or as well as Alfred. Man,
why&#39;d he get so hung up on the orphan
thing? He had surrogate parents queuing
around the [ __ ] block. He also has a
n brotherly relationship with Harvey
Dent growing up, so expect the two-face
origin story to also get retold for the
teenth time. This all has the same
effect the Gotham TV show had on me,
making me yell questions like, &quot;Is there
anyone in Batman&#39;s later career who
didn&#39;t interact with Bruce Wayne as a
child?&quot; And when are Penguin and Riddler
finally going to snog? Anyway, the plot
is Gotham, the city that has never once
in its entire history not been in the
grip of something, is in the grip of a
gang called the rats. Disenfranchised
poor people protesting income
inequality. Ooh, how relevant. When
Batman is implicated in the murder of a
rat who was in fact committing suicide
to prove a point, old grumpy tights
starts to wonder, &quot;Huh, maybe I need to
rethink my whole approach to this. Maybe
people turn to crime because of poverty
and societal factors rather than
inherent character flaws. And maybe
that&#39;s a problem that can&#39;t be fixed by
elbow smashing their legs so their knees
go the wrong way.&quot; And as a chorus of
onlookers cry, &quot;Fucking duh,&quot; he vows to
go undercover as a criminal in Black
Gate Prison. To both uncover the
identity of the mysterious leader, the
rat king, and gain a better
understanding of the criminal mindset.
In practice, he ends up smashing an
awful lot of legs, so their knees go the
wrong way, but some of them belong to
prison guards, and that&#39;s character
growth of a sort. I suppose there&#39;s a
bit of synchronized cake ownership and
consumption going on here as the plot
wants to follow the Batman&#39;s lead and
get all chinstroky about societal
inequality and ultimately Batman&#39;s
effectiveness as crime prevention, but
it also wants to be larger than life in
the established Arkham style so all the
disaffected poor people have to be huge
musclebound martial artists in rat
costumes, reciting revolutionary slogans
in exaggerated New York gangster
accents. I say it&#39;s a full-on Arkham
game, it&#39;s a stripped down one, more a
six- piece than a 20piece McNugget box.
The main setting is Black Gate Prison,
which isn&#39;t Arkham Asylum, but
apparently shares the same interior
designer and many of the same prisoners
somehow. Don&#39;t know why the [ __ ] joke
is here. Maybe they have an exchange
program. You split your time between
being Batman investigating the prison
after hours and undercover bat boss
pursuing leads on the dayshift, with
both modes providing plenty of chances
to get around [ __ ] guards with
stealth and get around [ __ ] kneecap
connective tissue with elbow smashes.
The free flow combat translates
relatively well to VR. You&#39;ll hate it if
you&#39;re one of those people who turned
the counter icons off in the other games
cuz sometimes this is like Batman&#39;s
mascot infected with spyw wear. There&#39;s
so many indicators from countering to
picking targets to punching the little
glowing circles to finish a dude off.
Still, Arkham Combat has always been
about the sheer satisfaction of Batman&#39;s
punches colliding with the sound of
freight trains plowing into orphanages.
And that&#39;s all the more intensified when
you&#39;re physically punching the air. I
could never land critical strikes in the
other games, but I can hear because they
depend on how hard you hit rather than
timing. And I always get slightly
embarrassingly into the VR motions cuz I
can tell myself it counts as exercise.
The translation of the stealthy predator
stuff is a little wobblier because
something seems to have gone wrong with
the guard&#39;s pathf finding. I&#39;d string
one up on a gargoyle and then have to
sit up in the rafters doing today&#39;s bat
wle while I wait for the other guards to
stop milling around beneath them trying
to scratch their itchy bums on the
handrail. Also, the way you have to
spread your arms to do a cape glide is
pathetic. Frankly, every time I do it, I
feel like a severely unmotivated Dracula
impersonator. It rarely took on the
first attempt. And I have long arms. I
kept misjudging my position in my play
space and smashing my hands into walls,
furniture, and small dogs. Besides all
that, the stealth is functional, if
again a little stripped down to
accommodate all the extra fiddliness of
VR, like when you fail to use a batarang
in a tight spot because you didn&#39;t pinch
your fingers in front of your chest in
precisely the desired manner. So, that&#39;s
core gameplay. There&#39;s also side
objectives and collectibles. You have
rat statues instead of Riddler trophies,
but there&#39;s no real benefit to glean
besides completionism and the fun sound
they make when you fling them at a wall.
You don&#39;t even get to punch the Riddler
in the face at the end of it and ruin
his future penguin snogging prospects.
But if you want to talk about what I
find generally disappointing about
Arkham Shadow, it&#39;s the lack of that
unique Batman Arkham fantastical streak.
You run into Two-Face, Scarecrow, and
Harley Quinn, but all in previllainy
phases of their lives. So, they&#39;re
basically all just dudes. Dudes with
jobs. The closest thing to a classic
Arkham over the top super villain fight
is against some nobody prison guard
who&#39;s inexplicably 10t tall. Again, a
dude with a job. There&#39;s also an
obnoxiously hard fight against a mod
boss where you have to split your
attention between punching goons,
planting bombs, and flinging batarangs
at a dude with a minigun. And while
firing the minigun probably isn&#39;t the
dude&#39;s job, he&#39;s certainly an
enthusiastic hobbyist. All right, fine.
The third and only other boss fight is
against a giant hallucination monster
Batman. But that doesn&#39;t score points
cuz Suicide Squad did the same [ __ ]
thing. And that&#39;s like copying from the
exam paper of the remedial student who,
it turns out all along was writing on a
square of used toilet paper. Well, let&#39;s
set up our little deck chairs in the
usual blasted no man&#39;s land of January.
Made all the more bleak by everyone
being huddled in their bunkers waiting
for the Grand Theft Auto 6 launch date
to drop and land on everyone&#39;s schedules
like the [ __ ] Tongaskker event. So,
let&#39;s indulge our regular routine of
tying up the loose ends from 2024. Such
as, why didn&#39;t you do anything with
Concord, Yati? Surely AAA publishers
getting buggered over an ironing board
is the thing you picture in your mind
every time you blow out your birthday
candles. Sony&#39;s half billion live
service failure should have been red
meat to you. It certainly was, listener,
but all the best chops of the red meat
got taken before I even got to the
carcass. I didn&#39;t even have a chance to
play Concord. It had come and gone from
online stores by the time I even heard
what a delightful shitfest it was.
Nothing one can do now but retroactively
take the piss out of the character
designs. And I&#39;d like to think that&#39;s
beneath me. I really would like to think
that

&gt;&gt; Animal Well,
&gt;&gt; I&#39;m a little embarrassed about this one.
I played Animal Well and found it to be

everyone kept going on about how it had

I apologize, Animal Well, it&#39;s not you,
it&#39;s me. I got tired of searching every

Eve.
&gt;&gt; Mouthwashing.
a short horror adventure experience that
I was hesitant to fully review because
it isn&#39;t very long and only barely

thanks to some slightly annoying arcadey
bits and several inventory puzzles where

recommendations go, it&#39;s a heavily
qualified one. Hey, check this game out.
It&#39;s really horrible and upsetting.
You&#39;ll love it. The premise is a small
group of low-level workers on a
spaceship crew under the heel of a
massive uncaring corporation are
stranded by a disaster with no certainty
of rescue and nothing to eat but a cargo
of mouthwash. And through a series of
events and hallucination sequences
presented in nonlinear order, the
situation inevitably decays and we
discover that everything was completely
[ __ ] from the start and they might as
well have all cut their [ __ ] throats
from the word go. So yeah, feel good hit
of the summer but made weirdly
compelling through some unique iconic
visuals. It&#39;s so what&#39;s the word?
visceral. It really helped me appreciate
how context and sound design can make an
act as simple as opening someone&#39;s mouth
for them into something really bloody
gross.
&gt;&gt; The casting of Frank Stone.
&gt;&gt; I&#39;ve kept my eye on Super Massive Games
and their parade of glorified choose

an oncologist keeps their eye on a
worrying growth on somebody&#39;s prostate.
But I do think there&#39;s potential there.
Until Dawn and Man of Midan were all

didn&#39;t think it worth reviewing because
there&#39;d been no improvement in any of
Super Massive&#39;s key problem areas. Tuit,
their inability to come up with a single
[ __ ] character who didn&#39;t richly
deserve a brick to the teeth. None of

when your choices start mattering too

And I figured I already knew how it came
about. Behavior Interactive wanting to
bank off a successful live service game
for the rest of their [ __ ] lives. and
a whole bunch of owners of defunct
horror IPs needing to earn a living and
there only being so many conventions in
a year.
